docs.lead_paragraph: Intesa SanPaolo has cleaned out its books with a 5.8 billion-euro ($7.95 billion) write-down on its investments as it joined other Italian banks in preparing for a rigorous Europe-wide stress test, while announcing a slate of asset sales under a plan to boost earnings and dividends.

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite a late surge in sign-ups, support for President Barack Obama's health care law is languishing at its lowest level since passage of the landmark legislation four years ago, according to a new poll.

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 6 million people have now signed up for private insurance plans under President Barack Obama's signature healthcare law known as Obamacare, reflecting a surge in enrollments days before the March 31 deadline, the White House said on Thursday.

docs.abstract: The cost of a new treatment for hepatitis C has renewed a debate about drug prices and whether its cost exceeds the price society is willing to pay, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: With the first open enrollment period set to end Monday, the Affordable Care Act looks less like a sweeping federal overhaul than a collection of individual ventures playing out unevenly, state to state, in the laboratories of democracy.

headline.main: Deadline Near, Health Signups Show Disparity
headline.print_headline: Deadline Near, Health Signups Show Disparity

docs.abstract: Affordable Care Act, with first open enrollment period set to end, looks less like sweeping federal overhaul than collection of individual ventures playing out unevenly, state to state; more than six million people are enrolled in private plans; experts warn focus on national numbers is misguided, and that it will take years to fully assess law's impact.
docs.snippet: With the first open enrollment period set to end Monday, the Affordable Care Act looks less like a sweeping federal overhaul than a collection of individual ventures playing out unevenly, state to state, in the laboratories of democracy.
